tt_insn_vec.help: Portion of vector registers that is actually used. Available only for instructions belonging to a SIMD/vector instructions set (like x86 AVX)

tt_Recip_throughput.help: Average number of cycles to retire that instruction if repeated (assuming independent instructions, with no read-after-write dependency)

hint.workaround:
- Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
 - Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
hint.details:
- Constant non-unit stride: 1 occurrence(s)
Non-unit stride (uncontiguous) accesses are not efficiently using data caches
hint.title: Slow data structures access
hint.txt: Detected data structures (typically arrays) that cannot be efficiently read/written

hint.workaround:
- Pass to your compiler a micro-architecture specialization option:
  * Please look into your compiler manual for march=native or equivalent
 - Use vector aligned instructions:
  1) align your arrays on 64 bytes boundaries
  2) inform your compiler that your arrays are vector aligned: read your compiler manual.
<<image_vec_align>>
hint.title: Vector unaligned load/store instructions
hint.txt: Detected 2 suboptimal vector unaligned load/store instructions.

hint.title: Type of elements and instruction set
hint.txt: No instructions are processing arithmetic or math operations on FP elements. This loop is probably writing/copying data or processing integer elements.

hint.title: Matching between your loop (in the source code) and the binary loop
hint.txt:
The binary loop does not contain any FP arithmetical operations.
The binary loop is loading 32 bytes.
The binary loop is storing 32 bytes.

hint.workaround: Unroll your loop if trip count is significantly higher than target unroll factor and if some data references are common to consecutive iterations. This can be done manually.
hint.title: Unroll opportunity

cycles | 0.75      | 0.75 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 1.33 | 1.33 | 1.33 | 0.00 | 0.00 | 0.00 | 0.00 | 1.00 | 1.00

Execution ports to units layout:
 - ALU0/BRU0: ALU, BRU
 - ALU1: ALU
 - ALU2: ALU
 - ALU3: ALU
 - BRU1: BRU
 - AGU0 (256 bits): store address, load
 - AGU1 (256 bits): store address, load
 - AGU2 (256 bits): store address, load
 - FP0 (256 bits): VPU, DIV/SQRT
 - FP1 (256 bits): VPU, DIV/SQRT
 - FP2 (256 bits): VPU
 - FP3 (256 bits): VPU
 - FP4 (256 bits): FP store data
 - FP5 (256 bits): FP store data

expert.help: Compare the CQA-computed load/store/compute metrics with the capacity of the core. For instance if CQA computes 24 bytes in the loop in 2 cycles (that is 12 cycles per cycle) and if the core can process up to 16 bytes per cycle, that metric is 75%.
expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 1.33 cycles. At this rate:
 - 25% of peak load performance is reached (24.00 out of 96.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
 - 37% of peak store performance is reached (24.00 out of 64.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

expert.help: List of bottlenecks detected by CQA. A bottleneck is an issue which reduces front-end throughput below the core capacity.
expert.title: Front-end bottlenecks

header: 0% of peak computational performance is used (0.00 out of 48.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
- Pass to your compiler a micro-architecture specialization option:
  * Please look into your compiler manual for march=native or equivalent
 - Use vector aligned instructions:
  1) align your arrays on 64 bytes boundaries
  2) inform your compiler that your arrays are vector aligned: read your compiler manual.
gain.details:
All SSE/AVX instructions are used in vector version (process two or more data elements in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a fully vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is vectorized, but using only 128 out of 512 bits (SSE/AVX-128 instructions on AVX-512 processors).
By fully vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 1.33 to 0.50 cycles (2.67x speedup).

gain.workaround:
- Read less array elements
 - Write less array elements
 - Provide more information to your compiler:
  * hardcode the bounds of the corresponding 'for' loop
gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt:
Performance is limited by:
 - reading data from caches/RAM (load units are a bottleneck)
 - writing data to caches/RAM (the store unit is a bottleneck)

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 1.33 to 1.17 cycles (1.14x speedup).
